_header: Here begins all medicines both sooth and true
_description: Verse introduction to an equine remedy book, Medicines for Horses — three couplets aabbcc

BodWoodEmpt18.Transcription:
Her begynnis all medesynis bothe sothe and trewyTo knowe & to
                    hele all sores both olde & newyWhych hath bene prouyde by a man of
                    pryceÞat hath wrytyn in thyse wyseFor þe whyche a lorde of
                    grete renowneGave hym þe hors schoo wyth þe crowne
BodWoodEmpt18.Editions:
Keiser,  George R. 
             “Verse Introductions to Middle English Medical Treatises.” 
             English Studies
         84 (2003): 301-17: 316.

BodWoodD18.First Lines:
Her endyth þe medesynes soth and trewTo hele all horses both
                    old & new…
BodWoodD18.Note: The verses serve as an epilogue in this MS.
BodWoodD18.Editions:
Keiser,  George R. 
             “Verse Introductions to Middle English Medical Treatises.” 
             English Studies
         84 (2003): 301-17: 316, n. 31.

BLSl686.First Lines:
Here endeth þe medicynes soth & trweTo hele all hors sorys
                    both old & newe…
BLSl686.Note: The verses serve as an epilogue in this MS.
BLSl686.Editions:
Keiser,  George R. 
             “Verse Introductions to Middle English Medical Treatises.” 
             English Studies
         84 (2003): 301-17: 316, n. 31.
